questions.text: During an Anesthetic procedure, a 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension accidentally receives an intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone. Immediately after the injection, he reports severe pain at the injection site and the affected limb becomes pale. Which of the following is the most likely complication this patient is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ischemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A . Inadvertent intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone can lead to severe complications , the most likely of which in this patient is ischemia . This occurs because the injection of the drug directly into an artery can cause thrombosis, vasospasm , and a lack of blood flow to the affected limb , resulting in ischemia. The initial symptom is typically burning pain , and the affected limb may become pale due to vasospasm . This complication is commonly seen when thiopentone is injected in antecubital vein because in 10% of the case brachial artery divides above elbow giving a very superficial abnormal ulnar artery which lies deep to antecubital vein . Therefore, thiopentone injection should be avoided at antecubital fossa and it should be given in the veins over the outer aspect of forearm .
